labels.analysis: The MCP Server is designed to manage and monitor multiple Kubernetes clusters through a centralized interface. Its tools enable cluster administration, resource management, rollout control, node maintenance, diagnosis, and cluster-wide operations. The functionality focuses on Kubernetes cluster orchestration, including both high-level operations (like rollouts) and low-level adjustments (like node cordoning/draining). It simplifies multi-cluster management by providing unified commands across different contexts.
labels.reasoning: The primary label is "Operating System" because the server primarily deals with managing cluster resources, node states, and deployment operationsâ€”core tasks of an operating system in a Kubernetes environment. Secondary labels include "Development Tools" due to debugging/rollout management and "Memory Management" for monitoring and scaling resources. No custom label is needed as predefined categories adequately cover its functionality.

tools.name: k8s_get_contexts
tools.description: List all available Kubernetes contexts from the kubeconfig files.

tools.name: k8s_get_namespaces
tools.description: List all namespaces in a specified Kubernetes context.

tools.name: k8s_get_nodes
tools.description: List all nodes in a Kubernetes cluster.

tools.name: k8s_get_resources
tools.description: List Kubernetes resources of a specified kind.

tools.name: k8s_get_pod_logs
tools.description: Get logs for a Kubernetes pod.

tools.name: k8s_get_events
tools.description: List Kubernetes events using specific context in a specified namespace.

tools.name: k8s_get_resource
tools.description: Get Kubernetes resource completely.

tools.name: k8s_top_nodes
tools.description: Display resource usage (CPU/memory) of nodes in a Kubernetes cluster.

tools.name: k8s_top_pods
tools.description: Display resource usage (CPU/memory) of pods in a Kubernetes cluster.

tools.name: k8s_rollout_status
tools.description: Get the status of a rollout for a deployment, daemonset, or statefulset.

tools.name: k8s_rollout_history
tools.description: Get the revision history of a rollout for a deployment, daemonset, or statefulset.

tools.name: k8s_rollout_undo
tools.description: Undo a rollout to a previous revision for a deployment, daemonset, or statefulset.

tools.name: k8s_rollout_restart
tools.description: Restart a rollout for a deployment, daemonset, or statefulset.

tools.name: k8s_rollout_pause
tools.description: Pause a rollout for a deployment, daemonset, or statefulset.

tools.name: k8s_rollout_resume
tools.description: Resume a rollout for a deployment, daemonset, or statefulset.

tools.name: k8s_scale_resource
tools.description: Scale a deployment, statefulset, or replicaset to the specified number of replicas.

tools.name: k8s_autoscale_resource
tools.description: Configure a Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) for a deployment, statefulset, or replicaset.

tools.name: k8s_update_resources
tools.description: Update resource requests and limits for a container in a deployment, statefulset, or daemonset.

tools.name: k8s_diagnose_application
tools.description: Diagnose issues with a Kubernetes application by checking resource status, events, and logs.

tools.name: k8s_apis
tools.description: List all available APIs in the Kubernetes cluster.

tools.name: k8s_crds
tools.description: List all Custom Resource Definitions (CRDs) in the Kubernetes cluster.

tools.name: k8s_describe
tools.description: Show detailed information about a specific resource or group of resources.

tools.name: k8s_create_resource
tools.description: Create a Kubernetes resource from YAML/JSON content.

tools.name: k8s_apply_resource
tools.description: Apply a configuration to a resource by filename or stdin.

tools.name: k8s_patch_resource
tools.description: Update fields of a resource.

tools.name: k8s_label_resource
tools.description: Update the labels on a resource.

tools.name: k8s_annotate_resource
tools.description: Update the annotations on a resource.

tools.name: k8s_expose_resource
tools.description: Expose a resource as a new Kubernetes service.

tools.name: k8s_set_resources_for_container
tools.description: Set resource limits and requests for containers.

tools.name: k8s_cordon_node
tools.description: Mark a node as unschedulable.

tools.name: k8s_uncordon_node
tools.description: Mark a node as schedulable.

tools.name: k8s_drain_node
tools.description: Drain a node in preparation for maintenance.

tools.name: k8s_taint_node
tools.description: Update the taints on one or more nodes.

tools.name: k8s_untaint_node
tools.description: Remove the taints from a node.

tools.name: k8s_pod_exec
tools.description: Execute a command in a container.

server_info_crawled.name: Multi Cluster Kubernetes Server
server_info_crawled.author: @razvanmacovei/k8s-multicluster-mcp
server_info_crawled.overview: Manage multiple Kubernetes clusters simultaneously through a unified interface. Perform cluster and resource management, monitoring, rollout control, and node maintenance across contexts using standardized commands. Simplify multi-cluster operations and diagnostics from a single MCP server.

server_info_crawled.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

config = {
  "kubeconfigDir": ""
}
# Encode config in base64
config_b64 = base64.b64encode(json.dumps(config).encode()).decode()
smithery_api_key = ""

# Create server URL
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@razvanmacovei/k8s-multicluster-mcp/mcp?config={config_b64}&api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())
